We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

>>2501981
You don't think that 50ft heads, shooting heads, specialized tapers, etc. are innovative? A 5wt rod is still a 5wt, its the lines that are different. Anybody who cant cast an AFTMA compliant line on a modern rod with the corresponding wt is bad at casting. I can underline an 8wt rod with a 150gr 5wt line and perform.

The reason overlining is common and effective is graphite. Graphite can handle a larger range of line grains than fiberglass. Ever fish a sinking line on older glass rods? They cannot handle it, while modern graphite rods can easily handle a 100gr+ over weighted sinking line and an AFTMA compliant floating line equally well.

Some rod companies are moving towards grain weight windows. TFO, Sage and T&T offer rods that specify grains for big fly/big game applications.

In the bullet analogy a fly rod would be a 30-06 rifle, the fly lines are bullets. You change the grain of the bullet (within reason) depending on what you need to accomplish while still using the same gun. Just like you use a different lines to fish streamers and dries without changing the rod.

Hi, I shoot 11/32" and 5/16" cedar spines. Mostly field tips, 125 grain for 11/32 and 100 grain for 5/16. 11/32 weigh around 550 grains and 5/16 weigh 440 grains. https://www.aliexpress.com/item/4000597422478.html?spm=a2g0o.productlist.0.0.212e5eacZbf2iR&algo_pvid=56cd105d-7ec5-4245-b54d-4d750caa8217&algo_exp_id=56cd105d-7ec5-4245-b54d-4d750caa8217-40&pdp_ext_f=%7B%22sku_id%22%3A%2210000003733794906%22%7D&pdp_npi=2%40dis%21AUD%2147.91%2146.47%21%21%212.61%21%21%402101e9ce16694949307697539e6d95%2110000003733794906%21sea&curPageLogUid=SH0YjxSA77Oo
I would buy link-related and cut them down if need be. Keep the arrow length the same. If you're shooting off the shelf you need a spine that has a bit of wobble and flex to it, which it sounds like those cedar arrows don't have. All mine are 500 spine which is a good mid-point for compound and recurve, but if you're just shooting off the shelf I would go for a 600. That's why they aren't flying straight, too stiff. Google "archers paradox". Did you start out using cedar? Do you have any cheap fiberglass arrows?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2499275
I own two multitools, the left one is a Leatherman Wave clone by Bibury. Great quality for the price. Just recently took it with me on a multiday trip. The pliers are great, but not springloaded. There is a knife with a straight edge, as well as a serrated edge. Both come very sharp from the factory. The scissors are great too. The bit holder uses standard bits rather than Leathermans proprietary design, which is a plus too. I think Americans can get some other form of Wave clone at Walmart. The left tool is the Nextool Flagship. This was my first multitool and it has a great pair of scissors. Both the scissors and pliers are spring loaded. All the knives, sawes and files on both tools feature liner locks.

After testing the Bibury I'd definitely recommend it over the Nextool, since you get more features in a slightly smaller form factor. It is heavier though.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Ideally you want a dehydrator that can reach 165F if you are doing meats, that temperature kills bacteria any bacteria that are cause for concern. If you are using a dehydrator that cannot achieve that temperature it is usually recommended that you pasteurize in the oven for like 10 minutes or so. It takes anywhere from 4-8 hours to do a batch of jerky depending on how thick I cut it. 1/8in roughly 4hrs, 1/4in roughly 6hrs, 3/8in roughly 8 hours. I bought a more powerful unit because I don't like leaving chink appliances running unattended for long extended periods of time and there was no way I was waiting 1-2 days for a batch.

depends largely on the stove design and what exact fuel you use like heet vs hardware store alcohol etc. also things like the altitude, weather, etc affect it especially if you're using a higher pressure alcohol stove design.
instead of giving you a generic answer that's probably wrong i'm going to tell you to boil a liter of water with a known volume of fuel in various weather conditions & time it to find out.
usually in alcohol stoves 1oz of generic fuel will get you boiling somewhere between 1-2 liters of water.
and rule of thumb: canister stove + fuel is lighter on longer trips, alcohol on shorter trips.

I had a filson but didnt like it for out that much. I much prefer the anorak designs.
If you do go with Filson, prioritize the plaids. The non plaids are made overseas, 24 oz and pill much easier. For the longest time Filson denied their wool cloth had changed but now say their plaids (still made in us) are 26 oz and closer to old fabric.
If you are willing to spend that amount of money id look at weatherwool or stormy kromer for a much better value. You can also find filsons on ebay that are vintage.

Lester river/empire canvas makes a great anorak but it is warm.

Genuine australian bushwear bush shirt

Asbell (us)

>>2501581
depending how far you have to travel you could put pic related in to encase it first. we did this with out pillar. the pillar itself was made from regular concrete mix in a 10" tube and we wheeled into the woods with a wooden yoke we made, but then to give it a solid base we dumped two bags of fast setting concrete into the hole before we sunk the pillar in. the quick setting stuff doesn't have to be mixed well, it's designed to be put in a hole dry and then you dump a small amount of water in (like a gallon or two) and stir it up a little. the water will soak any dry clumps before it sets, it's well designed. plus at the first rain it'll cure more completely anyway and then you'll have a solid 40 or 60 pound block of concrete as a vault

Most people dying from hypothermia is not in the freezing winter, but casual unprepared hikers getting wet in the rain and it's only ~10c or so. They probably have a cotton t-shirt, cotton sweat shirt or hoodie, cotton pants/jeans, cotton socks, cotton underwear. They'll quickly cool down, start panic and possibly get lost or too far away from civilization.

In freezing temperatures cotton is alright because it doesn't really get wet.
There is tight woven cotton that is water resistant. Not sure how good it is.
Most outdoor cotton gear is mix with poly, 35-40% cotton, 60-65% poly. In my experience that will dry up fairly quickly.

In my experience, going fishing its a great way to start going /out/.
You dont need a lot of money to start doing it, you dont need to be very experienced since you can fish very close from a parking lot, and there Is a lot of tutorials in YouTube, also, you will learn what kind of clothes are good for being outside for long time, and what you need to bring (food, water, tools, etc)
Once you get confortable fishing during a whole day, you can start camping+fishing, to go one step further hiking+fishing+camping (at this point you can consider yourself a true /out/ist) then you can do camping+hiking only trips, and at this point you can start mountaineering. And It all starts with the humble zebco rod+reel combo.
Of course, I started fishing when I was 6.

I hike/backpack and mountain bike, if you like cycling at all mountain biking is really fun.

Do I need to go to school or have experience to do forestry?

Do all the workers have to put out fires? Can you work only during certain seasons?

Is it worth the pay if you have no experience (so they will pay you less)?

Is it worth doing just to try if you don’t want an entire career out of it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Following to get updates!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500269
>Do I need to go to school or have experience to do forestry?
No, but you'll be apply against people that do have those. I applied to be a Park Ranger and couldn't even get that.
>Do all the workers have to put out fires? Can you work only during certain seasons?
From what they told me in the interview, most of the work is firefighting. Year round work, at least in my case it was.
>Is it worth the pay if you have no experience (so they will pay you less)?
According to the interview, the state sets the salary for the position and experience/college doesn't matter. It also pays about the same as working at McDonalds or Walmart.
>Is it worth doing just to try if you don’t want an entire career out of it?
That's all I wanted to do, but I didn't get the job. The interview made it pretty appealing as a career though even with the shit pay, mostly all the government benefits and how quickly you can "finish your service" and retire.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500269
>Do I need to go to school or have experience to do forestry?
What he said
>>2500284

>Do all the workers have to put out fires? Can you work only during certain seasons?
No, but you usually have to have your 64 hour class or whatever the fuck it is now. There are seasonal positions but you have to worry about getting a call back next season, and you'll probably be stringing Christmas lights or some bullshit in the off season.
>Is it worth the pay if you have no experience (so they will pay you less)?
No, not unless you do something moderately important and even then it's not great, but damn is it fun.
>Is it worth doing just to try if you don’t want an entire career out of it?
If you can get in, fuck yeah. What you do on the fire line will be your baseline work ethic for the rest of your life. A hand crew on the fire line is probably one of the hardest jobs out there. Best job I ever had.
